channel.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
channel.description:
Hey, so i'm basically cleaning my client.java out by making new classes and handling the methods in there. But how would I 'connect' client.java to a new class. i.e;
I get this error:
[code]Error: cannot find symbol Deletewalls();[/code]
but what if i had that method in for example public class deletewalls
how would i make it like this in client.java
[code]deletewalls.Deletewalls();[/code]
thanks

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @sertan8 sertan8
item.description:
@sertan8 wrote:

Thanks guys, figured it out

Read full topic
item.source: Making client.java connect with a new class

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:14, topic:542156”]Dan0194 then you’re not using OOP properly. You’re pointlessly using the static modifier when you have no design pattern in mind nor is it a utility class. OOP is not just having a ton of classes.

Edit: sertan8 http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/IandI/polymorphism.html
or look into Inheritance http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/IandI/subclasses.html[/quote]
Obviously not but just because you made an instance of the class doesn’t mean it’s OOP.

To make this OOP he could use abstraction.

Read full topic

@Ashi wrote:

Dan0194 then you’re not using OOP properly. You’re pointlessly using the static modifier when you have no design pattern in mind nor is it a utility class. OOP is not just having a ton of classes.

Edit: sertan8 http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/IandI/polymorphism.html

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @sertan8 sertan8
item.source: Making client.java connect with a new class

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:11, topic:542156”]Just spoonfeed him jeez.

[code=java]public class MyClass {
private Client client;

public MyClass(Client client) {
    this.client = client;
}

//rest of the methods you want.

}[/code]

In Client.java

private MyClient mc = new MyClient(this); mc.method();

Easiest way to accomplish what you’re trying to do.

Also if you really want to use polymorphism, I ain’t going to stop you lol[/quote]
I did spoon feed him at the top of my first post. Honestly a static method makes more sense here than instancing the whole class.

Read full topic
item.source: Making client.java connect with a new class

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Just spoonfeed him jeez.

[code=java]public class MyClass {
private Client client;

public MyClass(Client client) {
    this.client = client;
}

//rest of the methods you want.

}[/code]

In Client.java

private MyClass mc = new MyClass(this); mc.method();

Easiest way to accomplish what you’re trying to do.

Also if you really want to use polymorphism, I ain’t going to stop you lol

Read full topic
item.source: Making client.java connect with a new class

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

sertan8:

yes

Okay say I make a new java file named Example.

Inside of it I put a method execute();

my execute method let’s say is static so it would look like this.

public static void execute() { //all stuff here }

Now My final product of the class would be.

[code=java5]public class Example {

public static void execute() {
//all stuff here
}

}[/code]

So if I wanted to use the method execute from my Example class(or java file).

You would put this anywhere in your client.java Example.execute();

Read full topic

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“sertan8, post:7, topic:542156”]lol can u give me an example

You make the lol method static and inside it’s parameters pass on your client instance.

I think I know what you mean but that’s not my issue.

I mean inside client.java I want it to make lol.lol();

So basically inside client.java it needs to use the method in the lol class[/quote]

You are asking how you can use a method from the lol class inside your client class right?

Read full topic

item.description:
@sertan8 wrote:

lol can u give me an example

You make the lol method static and inside it's parameters pass on your client instance.

I think I know what you mean but that’s not my issue.

I mean inside client.java I want it to make lol.lol();

So basically inside client.java it needs to use the method in the lol class

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“sertan8, post:5, topic:542156”]I know what you mean, I’ve already done that and it worked… Either you haven’t answered my question or I just don’t know what I mean (probably this) but I mean like

what if there was this in client.java
somewhere

lol();

and I would have removed the public void lol out of client.java and put it in lol.java

how would I make it lol.lol(); ??[/quote]
You make the lol method static and inside it’s parameters pass on your client instance. You are also going to need to add client. to almost everything.

Tell me the errors you received though on my previous post.

Read full topic

item.source: Making client.java connect with a new class

item.title: Making client.java connect with a new class
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“sertan8, post:3, topic:542156”]oh my god are you for real

you don’t even know what my question is do you[/quote]
What Ashi said is right you need to learn how objects work.

He was a bit vague but first of all you should be using an interface to handle packets or something similar to that but since you just want to clean out your client.java. You would make a new class named

FirstClickObject

and then inside you would make a static method named:

public static void handlePacket(Client client, int objectId, int objectX, int objectY) { //all stuff here }

Again I recommend you reading up on abstraction because you can make this a lot more OO if you did. Btw to call it you world do

P.S. First Click object is packet opcode 132 or case 132.

Read full topic
